subject: PRE-MARKET AUSTRALIA, JAPAN AND SOUTH KOREA STOCK NEWS: Richard Branson is to sell 25mln shares in Virgin Galactic to provide support for his travel empire including Virgin Australia, while InterGlobe is also interested in the Co.
content:
AUSTRALIA

A2B Australia (A2B AT) - NSW government is close to finalizing package for Sydney taxis. (Newswires)

Altium (ALU AT) - Co. expects prolongation of coronavirus-related restrictions to impact Co. this month and next, while it will likely miss its rev. target. (Newswires)

AusNet Services (AST AT) - Co. FY net AUD 290.7mln vs. Prev. AUD 253.9mln Y/Y, final dividend of 5.10 cents per share, while reports note chatter that Co. could conduct a capital raising valued at AUD 300mln-500mln. (AFR)

CSR (CSR AT) - Co. FY20 adj. net AUD 125.3mln vs. Prev. AUD 181.7mln Y/Y, Co. suspends share buyback. (Newswires)

Kogan.com (KGN AT) - Co. April gross profit rose over 150% and gross sales rose more than 100%. (Newswires)

New Hope Corporation (NHC AT) - Co. announced retirement of CEO and MD effective August 31st. (Newswires)

Nine Entertainment (NEC AT) - Anacacia Capital held discussions about acquiring Nine Entertainment’s New Zealand assets. (Newswires)

Virgin Australia (VAH AT) - Richard Branson is to sell 25mln shares in Virgin Galactic to provide support for his travel empire including Virgin Australia. There were also separate reports that suggested India’s InterGlobe Aviation (INDIGO IS) is putting together a proposal for Virgin Australia. (Newswires/AFR)

Airlines - Regional Express is planning to launch new capital city routes which would increase the competition for Qantas (QAN AT) and Virgin Australia (VAH AT). (Newswires)

 

JAPAN

ABC-MART (2670 JT) - Co. April same store sales fell 45.2% Y/Y. (Newswires)

Bridgestone (5108 JT) - Co. reportedly to seek JPY 500bln capital raise and has replaced its COO after just a year and a half. (Nikkei)

Chiba Bank (8331 JT) - Co. FY net JPY 48.0bln vs. Prev. JPY 50.5bln Y/Y. (Newswires)

Fuji Oil Holdings (2607 JT) - Co. FY net loss JPY 29.1bln vs. Prev. profit JPY 2.9bln Y/Y. (Newswires)

Hino Motors (7205 JT) - Co. FY net JPY 31.5bln vs. Prev. JPY 54.9bln Y/Y. (Newswires)

KDDI (9433 JT) - Co. may report FY oper. profit of JPY 1.3tln vs. guidance of JPY 1.0tln. (Nikkei)

Kobe Steel (5401 JT) - Co. prelim. FY net loss JPY 68.0bln vs. Prev. profit JPY 35.9bln Y/Y. (Newswires)

Kyushu Railway (9142 JT) - Co. FY net JPY 31.5bln vs. Prev. JPY 49.2bln Y/Y. (Newswires)

Mitsubishi Heavy (7011 JT) - Co. expects no profit for the year due to impact from coronavirus. (Nikkei)

Mitsubishi UFJ Financial Group (8306 JT) - Co. is to issue Japan’s first coronavirus bond. (Nikkei)

Nissan (7201 JT) - Co. reports April China sales rose 1.1% Y/Y to 122.9k units. (Newswires)

Osaka Gas (9532 JT) - Co. FY net JPY 41.8bln vs. Prev. JPY 33.6bln Y/Y. (Newswires)

ROUND ONE (4680 JT) - Co. April same store sales fell 96.1 Y/Y. (Newswires)

SoftBank (9434 JT) - Co. FY net JPY 473.1bln vs. Prev. JPY 462.5bln Y/Y. (Newswires)

Tokai Carbon (5301 JT) - Co. Q1 net JPY 4.6bln vs. Prev. JPY 13.2bln Y/Y. (Newswires)

 

SOUTH KOREA

Doosan Heavy (034020 KS) - Co. is said to be seeking to sell Seoul building for KRW 700bln. (Newswires)

GS Holdings (078930 KS) - Co. Q1 net loss KRW 295.2bln vs. Prev. profit KRW 205.8bln Y/Y. (Newswires)

Hyundai Greenfood (005440 KS) - Co. Q1 net rose 13% Y/Y to KRW 41.1bln. (Newswires)

NCsoft (036570 KS) - Co. Q1 net KRW 195.5bln vs. Prev. KRW 118.8bln Y/Y. (Newswires)

Other News - South Korea is said to delay re-opening of schools by one week amid increase in coronavirus cases linked to clubs. (Newswires)

Geopolitics 

South Korean President Moon says they remain committed to pushing for another inter-Korean summit with North Korea leader Kim within the year. (Newswires)

South Korean and US intelligence authorities suggested that the new strategic weapon that North Korean leader Kim mentioned last year is likely to be a submarine equipped with multiple ballistic missiles. (Dong-A)

ASIAN DAILY ECONOMIC RELEASES CALENDAR IS NOW AVAILABLE IN THE RESEARCH SECTION: Highlights include: Australian Home Loans and NAB Business Surveys, Chinese CPI and PPI, Japanese 10yr Bond Auction
DAILY ASIA-PAC OPENING NEWS
content:
CORONAVIRUS UPDATE / RESPONSES

US Treasury Secretary Mnuchin said virus numbers should go down into the summer as economies re-open and that it does not appear there will be bipartisan support for next COVID support bills. (Newswires)

UK COVID-19 death toll rose to 32,065 (Prev. 31,855) with deaths increasing by 210 vs. Prev. 269, while case count rose by 3,877 vs. Prev. 3,923 increase. (Newswires)

Turkey President Erdogan announced a four-day lockdown from May 16th until after the May 19th national holiday. (Newswires)

 

ASIA-PAC

Chinese officials may consider invalidating the Phase One trade deal or negotiating a new one to “tilt the scales more to the Chinese side” after US President Trump’s hyped anti-China conspiracy, according to Global Times citing sources. This also follows reports that some Chinese officials were calling for new negotiations on the US Phase One deal. (Global Times)

Chinese Premier Li said the government will step up macroeconomic policy adjustments and will strive to achieve economic and social development targets. (Newswires)

EU Trade Commissioner Hogan spoke with China's Commerce Minister and noted the EU is ready to make joint efforts with China to conclude negotiations over the China-EU bilateral investment treaty within the year. (Global Times)

  • Chinese New Yuan Loans (CNY)(Apr) 1700B vs. Exp. 1400B (Prev. 2850B) . (Newswires)
  • Chinese Aggregate Financing (CNY)(Apr) 3090B vs. Exp. 2278B (Prev. 5150B)
  • Chinese M2 Money Supply (Apr) Y/Y 11.1% vs. Exp. 10.2% (Prev. 10.1%)

 

UK/EU

UK government detailed guidelines stated that government financial support measures cannot be sustained for a prolonged time, while UK PM Johnson said that parliament will hear more on the furlough scheme tomorrow. (Newswires)

UK Brexit negotiators are to reportedly tell the EU that a new fisheries agreement cannot be part of a free trade agreement. (Telegraph)

 

COMMODITIES

Saudi Aramco has been directed to cut its crude oil production in excess of the OPEC+ cuts by an additional 1mln BPD for June, which would bring the total cut to 4.8mln BPD from April production level to 7.49mln BPD. Saudi Arabia said the additional cuts in output are designed to support rebalancing the market and encourages other producers to make further voluntary cuts, while they would be more than surprised if by the next OPEC+ meeting in June the picture is not brighter. (Newswires)

UAE Energy Minister said the country will take an additional 100k BPD cut in June and Kuwait is also to cut oil output by an additional 80k BPD in June on top of its OPEC+ commitment. (Newswires)

Note: It was reported last month that Saudi, UAE and Kuwait will voluntarily over comply by an additional 2mln BPD. 

 

US

Fed’s Quarles (voter) said banks are well-positioned to be a source of strength not strain in the current crisis, while he reiterated the view from other members that the Fed may be required to do more before the end of the crisis. (Newswires)

Fed's Bostic (non-voter) said he is not a "big fan" of negative rates and considers it among the weaker tools in the tool kit, while he does not believe the Fed would be inclined to buy equities. Bostic added that inflation could come one day, but not in the next six to twelve months and that the Fed would respond "accordingly" if it were to come. (Newswires)

Fed's Evans (non-voter) said he does not anticipate negative rates would be used as a tool in the US but sees rates near zero for quite some time. Evans added that a return-to-growth scenario in H2 2020 is only "a bit" more likely than the more pessimistic scenarios and added that while there is evidence that recent monetary and fiscal policy is cushioning the blow, more stimulus will be needed. (Newswires)

 

MARKET RECAP

US stock futures were on the front-foot overnight, supported by headlines suggesting that the PBOC would provide greater support. However, downside in European trade was attributed to punchy US/China headlines from Chinese press, as well as some concerns about COVID stats rising as European economies re-open. After the Europeans left for the day, a falling VIX and thin news flow allowed stocks to tick higher, led by the NQ, although there didn’t appear to be a specific catalyst (desks note technical and flows will influence trade in these conditions). Momentum/defensive names performed well today with MTUM +1.7%, while technology outperformed with the software focused ETF (FDN) reaching all-time highs; NDQ outperformed the SPX and DJIA. On Wednesday, Cisco (CSCO) report its figures, with analysts paying close attention to the results given its usefulness as a current barometer for the wider tech sector. Apple (AAPL) is in talks with Indian government officials to move up to USD 40bln of production to India from China, according to The Economic Times. President Trump’s administration and semiconductor companies are reportedly looking to start the development of new chip factories in the US amid concerns about reliance on Asia for technology, according to WSJ. Tesla (TSLA) Model 3 China Sales -64% M/M in April. CEO Musk announced the Co is to leave California immediately after regulations stopped Tesla from restarting production at its Fremont factory, although Verge later reported it has already begun manufacturing vehicles at its Fremont factory. SPX +0.01% at 2930, NDQ +0.85% at 9299, DJIA -0.45% at 24,222.

The TPLEX sold off on Monday amid a chunky supply pipeline and strength in equities. Yields had been heading modestly lower in European trade as equity futures reversed their strength set at the open on Sunday, however, a pick-up in equities, led by the NQ, saw duration come under pressure. Furthermore, participants had, and still have, a slew of supply to digest this week, where the US sold USD 42bln of three-year notes as part of its refunding today (stopped through the 0.233% WI by 0.3bps, covered 2.54x and Dealers took 32.59%). At the same time, the Dollar corporate issuance continued to churn post Q1 earnings, with today’s big deals pricing include Disney’s USD 11bln six-trancher and PayPal’s USD 4bln four-trancher. By settlement, yields were up between 3-6bps (3 on the short-end, 6 on the long-end) and the curve had bear-steepened. US T-note futures (M0) settled 10+ ticks lower at 138-20.

Newsquawk US Market Wrap - May 11th: Indecisive start to the week sees equities mixed
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

  • SNAPSHOT: Equities mixed, Treasuries down, Dollar up, Crude down.
  • REARVIEW: Punchy US/China rhetoric; Evans & Bostic against NIRP; EC float legal action against GCC; Additional OPEC cuts
  • COMING UP: Data: Chinese CPI, US CPI. Event: EIA STEO Speakers: Fed's Bullard, Harker & Mester. Supply: Germany & US. Earnings: Allianz, Deutsche Post, E.ON

MARKET WRAP

US stock futures were on the front-foot overnight, supported by headlines suggesting that the PBOC would provide greater support. However, downside in European trade was attributed to punchy US/China headlines from Chinese press, as well as some concerns about COVID stats rising as European economies re-open. After the Europeans left for the day, a falling VIX and thin news flow allowed stocks to tick higher, led by the NQ, although there didn’t appear to be a specific catalyst (desks note technicals and flows will influence trade in these conditions. The gains, however, lacked conviction as SPX finished flat; NDX outperformed. Treasuries bear-steepened; we get upsized Treasury offerings in the 3-year, 10-year (Tue) and 30-year (Wed) space this week; the former was digested with seeming ease on Monday, stopping through the screens by 0.3bps. However, the MOVE index (The VIX equivalent for Treasuries) has seen a recent move higher, which warrants caution given the VIX, which now sits comfortably below 30, has historically followed it, although the MOVE does still sit at historically low levels and significantly below its March peak. Meanwhile, the dollar has had a slightly firmer bias, although gold traded mixed around USD 1,700. Oil was initially supported by positive supply-side news flow, where the Saudi/UAE/Kuwait block have cut output for June by more than their OPEC+ obligations, though analysts noted that sourced reports from April implied they would have cut by a greater additional amount than reported today. This week, we will be watching Fed chair Powell comments on Wednesday, US CPI on Tuesday and retail sales on Thursday. Additionally, there will be an eye on the 10-year and 30-year supply to see how it is digested at these yields and while the Treasury is ramping-up issuance.

NORTH AMERICA

US/CHINA: Over the weekend, US officials acknowledged China was largely delivering its pledges on structural issues such as opening market access and improving IP protection, but they are yet to agree in some details including IP action plan and easing equity caps for foreign investors. Furthermore, the source stated fallout from the virus meant agreement on purchasing US goods has become much more important and that many believe China needs to increase pace on purchases, while a Chinese government adviser suggested the deal itself was fragile, according to reports. Source reports from China Global times saw a hawkish tone from China and reportedly called for a re-negotiation of the Phase One deal. The piece noted Chinese dissatisfaction amid compromises the side made to press ahead with the Phase One deal, while Trump’s anti-China rhetoric and “cover up” of his handling of the pandemic reportedly saw advisers float the possibility of voiding the trade pact and renegotiating one skewed more towards China’s interests. Another official, citing US’ staggering economy and the Presidential Election, said "It's in fact in China's interests to terminate the current phase one deal. It is beneficial to us. The US now cannot afford to restart the trade war with China”. That being said, analysts believe China will only terminate the agreement as a “last option”. Click here for full analysis.

MNUCHIN: US Treasury Secretary Mnuchin noted virus numbers should go down into the summer, as economies re-open. On stimulus he noted it does not appear there will be bipartisan support for next COVID support Bills, adding democrats want to spend a lot of money. On rates, he did not comment on Fed interest rates but noted the Treasury is borrowing more money in long-term tenors to lock-in low the low rates. Mnuchin said there is no need to buy back debt, the Treasury is keeping some funds in reserve since it does not know which facilities and markets will need more funding. He added the Fed muni programme and asset-backed term loan facilities are to be up-and-running soon.

CENTRAL BANKS

FED: Bostic and Evans – both non-voters – announced the aversion to negative rates today. Evans said he doesn’t anticipate negative rates would be used, while Bostic said he is not a big fan and considers them as one of the weaker tools available to the Fed. The comments come ahead of Fed Chair Powell’s speech on Wednesday in which he will likely address NIRP amid several Fed Fund futures contracts moving above par. Meanwhile, Evans noted that while recent fiscal and monetary stimulus is cushioning the economic damage, more will be needed.

REPO: Demand at the NY Fed’s RRP operation fell to USD 123mln on Monday, which IFR highlights as the lowest takeup since February 14th. Meanwhile, demand for cash ticked up from dealers, where across the one-month term and overnight repo operation, USD 51.25bln of bids were submitted. The takeup in the regular repo operations began increasing at the tail-end of last week, and if sustained through this week, could be indicative of a heat-up of funding pressures. Furthermore, note that after relentless compression since the March blowout, the FRA-OIS spread widening slightly today, which if sustained, could be another barometer indicating renewed funding pressures.

PBOC: Over the weekend, the Chinese Central Bank promised to further cushion the impact of the pandemic but remained hesitant to signal a large stimulus move. The statement came after heated debates between Beijing’s top policymakers and the PBoC on the appropriate scale and funding for a package. Click here for full analysis

FIXED INCOME

US T-NOTE FUTURES (M0) SETTLED 10+ TICKS LOWER AT 138-20

The TPLEX sold off on Monday amid a chunky supply pipeline and strength in equities. Yields had been heading modestly lower in European trade as equity futures reversed their strength set at the open on Sunday, however, a pick-up in equities, led by the NQ, saw duration come under pressure. Furthermore, participants had, and still have, a slew of supply to digest this week, where the US sold USD 42bln of three-year notes as part of its refunding today (stopped through the 0.233% WI by 0.3bps, covered 2.54x and Dealers took 32.59%). At the same time, the Dollar corporate issuance continued to churn post Q1 earnings, with today’s big deals pricing include Disney’s USD 11bln six-trancher and PayPal’s USD 4bln four-trancher. By settlement, yields were up between 3-6bps (3 on the short-end, 6 on the long-end) and the curve had bear-steepened.

NEGATIVE RATES: Fed Funds futures unwound some of its recent strength today, away from NIRP. FF futures as early as Jan 2021 had moved above par at the end of last week, although today they have receded back below par, with the nearest contract above now being April 2021. Several desks have written recently that they view the move above par as that of a technical nature (e.g. short squeeze), rather than the market outright assuming the Fed will move into NIRP. BMO’s analysts noted that as long as the Fed does not completely rule out negative rates, we will continue to see parts of the funding markets move into NIRP, as participants essentially hedge the possibility of the Fed going negative, even if the probability is low. Ahead of Fed chair Powell’s speech on Wednesday, where he is expected to address the issue, Evans (non-voter) today said says he doesn't anticipate negative rates would be used, and Bostic (non-voter) said he's not a big fan of the policy and considers it among the weaker tools – note that they did not outright rule out the policy.

TACTICAL BIAS: Fed guidance on rates (staying at these low levels for the foreseeable), buying concentrated in the belly, and the possibility of yield curve control (YCC) is outweighing the flood of bill supply in the short-end of the curve, TD Securities argues, keeping rates anchored at low levels. Meanwhile, the long-end of the curve is under pressure as a result of rising Treasury supply. This should give the curve a steeper bias.

THIS WEEK’S SUPPLY: The Treasury will auction USD 42bln 3-year notes (Mon), USD 32bln 10-year notes (Tue), and USD 22bln 30-year bonds (Wed). This week's auction will be revealing, given the Treasury's boosted refunding announcement last week. UBS notes that this week, around USD 86bln cash will fall due, including around USD 58bln of redemptions and USD 29bln of coupons.

PREVIEW - 10-YEAR AUCTION: There is still demand for 10-year even at slightly higher yields than present, analysts say, citing price action after Wednesday’s Treasury refunding announcement when 10-year yields closed 3-4bps higher, but rallied on Thursday back to within the 0.60-65% range (and respected the 0.78% top-end of its broader range). BMO argues, and that the liquidity advantages of Treasury auctions will continue to bring in buyers, and notes that sponsorship seen in recent auctions has come despite a dramatic repricing in yields, and we have seen several stop-throughs at record low yields, even with record auction sizes. BMO thinks this is an encouraging sign that the supply can be absorbed with little concession, and it does not expect the broader 0.54-0.78% 10-year Treasury yield range will be challenged as a result of this week’s supply. It does, however, think there is a risk the high-yield could stop-out above 0.70%.

10-YEAR AUCTIONS RECENT HISTORY:

  • High yield: (prev. 0.782%, six-auction avg. 1.462%)
  • Tail: (prev. 0.7bps, six-auction avg. -0.1bps)
  • Bid-to-cover: (prev. 2.43x, six-auction avg. 2.46x)
  • Dealers: (prev. 27.6%, six-auction avg. 26.3%)
  • Direct: (prev. 13.2%, six-auction avg. 14.2%)
  • Indirect: (prev. 59.2%, six-auction avg. 59.6%)

CRUDE

WTI (M0) SETTLES USD 0.60 LOWER AT USD 24.14; WTI (N0) SETTLES USD 1.09 LOWER AT USD 25.08; BRENT (N0) SETTLES USD 1.34 LOWER AT USD 29.63/BBL

Oil prices settled lower to start the week after paring gains from reports of additional OPEC cuts. The crude oil futures had already been trundling lower into the European session as equity futures reversed gains after the Globex open on Sunday. However, oil prices jumped higher after the tape was hit with reports that Saudi Aramco was to take an additional 1mln BPD cut in June from its April levels, in addition to the recent OPEC+ agreement. Saudi noted the additional cuts were being made to expedite the rebalancing of the oil market. The Kingdom also said it had directed Aramco to seek to make additional cuts in May too. Following the announcement, Kuwait announced it is to cut its output by an additional 80k BPD in June; UAE Energy Minister said the country would take an additional 100k BPD cut in June. While the announcements saw futures move into the green, they ultimately faded back into negative territory as the Europeans wrapped up for the day. Citi’s energy analysts interpreted the reversal as a suggestion that the cuts were more defensive than the Saudi commenting about “getting ahead of the curve” would suggest. Perhaps it is telling that oil futures failed to benefit in the revived appetite for equities after the US cash equity open, although one could argue that today’s rally was that of a momentum/defensive nature, with value/cyclical sectors the underperformers, thus limiting energy demand too.

EQUITIES

CLOSING LEVELS: SPX +0.01% at 2930, NDQ +0.85% at 9299, DJIA -0.45% at 24,222.

SECTORS: Health Care +1.7%, IT +0.7%, Communications +0.7%, Discretionary +0.1%, Staples -0.2%, Utilities -0.5%, Real Estate -1.2%, Industrials -1.25%, Materials -1.5%, Energy -1.7%, Financials -1.9%

STOCK SPECIFICS: Momentum/defensive names performed well today with MTUM +1.7%, while technology outperformed with the software focused ETF (FDN) reaching all-time highs; NDQ outperformed the SPX and DJIA. On Wednesday, Cisco (CSCO) report its figures, with analysts paying close attention to the results given its usefulness as a current barometer for the wider tech sector. Apple (AAPL) is in talks with Indian government officials to move up to USD 40bln of production to India from China, according to The Economic Times. President Trump’s administration and semiconductor companies are reportedly looking to start the development of new chip factories in the US amid concerns about reliance on Asia for technology, according to WSJ. Tesla (TSLA) Model 3 China Sales -64% M/M in April. CEO Musk announced the Co is to leave California immediately after regulations stopped Tesla from restarting production at its Fremont factory, although Verge later reported it has already begun manufacturing vehicles at its Fremont factory. AbbVie (ABBV) completed its purchase of Allergan (AGN). Coty (COTY) agreed to sell its majority stake in its Wella, Clairol, OPI and GHD brands to KKR (KKR) in a USD 4.3bln deal. AMC Entertainment (AMC) reportedly held talks with Amazon (AMZN) regarding a potential takeover, according to the Daily Mail citing sources, although later reports denied that talks had taken place.

EARNINGS: Marriott (MAR) missed on EPS although beat on revenue while noting trends in Greater China are continuing to improve, adding it saw a marginal uptick in US occupancy over the past few weeks. Under Armour (UAA) missed on EPS and revenue, while announcing its quarterly restructuring and impairment chargers were USD 466mln. Cardinal Health (CAH) beat on EPS and revenue, while reaffirmed its FY20 guidance. ON Semiconductor (ON) missed on EPS and revenue, while guidance also fell short of expectations.

EUROPE

GERMAN COURT RULING: Over the weekend, European Commission (EC) President Von der Leyen floated the possibility of legal action against the German Constitutional Court (GCC) - following the latter’s ruling that the ECB’s Public Sector Purchase Programme (PSPP) did not respect the “principle of proportionality”, suggesting the ECB went beyond its mandate – thus violating German law. Click here for full analysis.

FX WRAP

USD: The DXY reclaimed 100 to the upside in a solid day of gains amid risk-averse morning trade, with equities opening in the red while haven sectors outperformed. A similar view was seen in FX with USD bid and cyclicals underperforming, although typical havens JPY/XAU/CHF were weaker against a rising dollar.

CNY: US/China reaffirmation of Phase One obligations has eased market concerns in the short-run, but are unlikely to end tensions given US elections in November, difficulties China might have in meeting its USD 200bln purchase agreement; that has evidently been seen in some of the punchy US/China trade headlines crossing the tape today, and while they did not result in distinct risk-off, they did inject a slight negative bias. Last week, Trump said he'd address the progress of Phase One within a week or two. GS explains that rising tensions can impact the yuan via reduced cross-border M&A and portfolio flows, or lower exporter FX conversion. GS advises clients to consider adding hedges for these risks via long USDCNH or long USD/other regional FX.

JPY: The Yen was weaker against the buck with USDJPY reclaiming 107.00 and extending to highs of 107.72 at highs. Japan returned from Golden Week at the tail end of last week, although desks had anticipated a complete return would not be seen until the start of this week, which could have played into today’s price action, with USDJPY up over 1%, a move not seen since the end of March. Japanese PM Abe said the government was ready to add further stimulus if required, while it is also expected to lift its national state of emergency across parts of Japan. HSBC notes that these stories boosted local stocks thus the inverse relationship with the Nikkei could be explaining JPY weakness.

EUR: The single currency was hit today with EURUSD finding support at 1.08 after EC President Von Der Leyen raised the idea of legal action against the German Constitutional Court (GCC) after it ruled the ECB’s PSPP did not respect the “principle of proportionality” which although is in favour of the ECB, it highlights disputes among Eurozone groups.

GBP: UK PM Johnson announced the base line of the economic reopening in phases and announced that those who cannot work from home should be encouraged to return to work, while schools will start with the younger pupils first. ING writes that the speech had a muted impact as markets focus on the lack of clarity rather than the re-opening plan; the bank expects Cable to trade between 1.2240-1.2520 this week. Brexit talks are also set to get underway again, with latest reports suggesting the UK are to tell the EU a new fisheries agreement cannot be part of the free trade agreement.

CYCLICALS (GBP, AUD, NZD): Cyclicals were hit amid bouts of risk-off, although cyclicals are off lows as equities reversed losses and entered positive territory, while the haven bid for USD continued to weigh elsewhere.

COMMODITY FX (CAD, RUB, MXN): All weaker against a firmer dollar today with oil prices initially trading in negative territory although all currency pairs are trading off highs against the buck as crude prices staged a short-lived early rebound spurred by Saudi Arabia instructing Saudi Aramco to cut an additional 1mln BPD on top of the OPEC+ deal. On CAD, Scotiabank writes “we still think USDCAD is stuck in a broad range around the 1.40 area but feel the generally positive backdrop for risk assets suggests some modest upside scope for the CAD”. TREASURY WRAP: US T-Note futures (M0) settle 10+ ticks lower at 138-20
analysis_details:
The TPLEX sold off on Monday amid a chunky supply pipeline and strength in equities. Yields had been heading modestly lower in European trade as equity futures reversed their strength set at the open on Sunday, however, a pick-up in equities, led by the NQ, saw duration come under pressure. Furthermore, participants had, and still have, a slew of supply to digest this week, where the US sold USD 42bln of three-year notes as part of its refunding today (stopped through the 0.233% WI by 0.3bps, covered 2.54x and Dealers took 32.59%). At the same time, the Dollar corporate issuance continued to churn post Q1 earnings, with today’s big deals pricing include Disney’s USD 11bln six-trancher and PayPal’s USD 4bln four-trancher. By settlement, yields were up between 3-6bps (3 on the short-end, 6 on the long-end) and the curve had bear-steepened. 

NEGATIVE RATES: Fed Funds futures unwound some of its recent strength today, away from NIRP. FF futures as early as Jan 2021 had moved above par at the end of last week, although today they have receded back below par, with the nearest contract above now being April 2021. Several desks have written recently that they view the move above par as that of a technical nature (e.g. short squeeze), rather than the market outright assuming the Fed will move into NIRP. BMO’s analysts noted that as long as the Fed does not completely rule out negative rates, we will continue to see parts of the funding markets move into NIRP, as participants essentially hedge the possibility of the Fed going negative, even if the probability is low. Ahead of Fed chair Powell’s speech on Wednesday, where he is expected to address the issue, Evans (non-voter) today said says he doesn't anticipate negative rates would be used, and Bostic (non-voter) said he's not a big fan of the policy and considers it among the weaker tools – note that they did not outright rule out the policy.

TACTICAL BIAS: Fed guidance on rates (staying at these low levels for the foreseeable), buying concentrated in the belly, and the possibility of yield curve control (YCC) is outweighing the flood of bill supply in the short-end of the curve, TD Securities argues, keeping rates anchored at low levels. Meanwhile, the long-end of the curve is under pressure as a result of rising Treasury supply. This should give the curve a steeper bias.

THIS WEEK’S SUPPLY: The Treasury will auction USD 42bln 3-year notes (Mon), USD 32bln 10-year notes (Tue), and USD 22bln 30-year bonds (Wed). This week's auction will be revealing, given the Treasury's boosted refunding announcement last week. UBS notes that this week, around USD 86bln cash will fall due, including around USD 58bln of redemptions and USD 29bln of coupons.

PREVIEW - 10-YEAR AUCTION: There is still demand for 10-year even at slightly higher yields than present, analysts say, citing price action after Wednesday’s Treasury refunding announcement when 10-year yields closed 3-4bps higher, but rallied on Thursday back to within the 0.60-65% range (and respected the 0.78% top-end of its broader range). BMO argues, and that the liquidity advantages of Treasury auctions will continue to bring in buyers, and notes that sponsorship seen in recent auctions has come despite a dramatic repricing in yields, and we have seen several stop-throughs at record low yields, even with record auction sizes. BMO thinks this is an encouraging sign that the supply can be absorbed with little concession, and it does not expect the broader 0.54-0.78% 10-year Treasury yield range will be challenged as a result of this week’s supply. It does, however, think there is a risk the high-yield could stop-out above 0.70%.

subject: CRUDE WRAP: WTI futures (M0) settles USD 0.60 lower at USD 24.14; WTI (N0) settles USD 1.09 lower at USD 25.08; Brent (N0) settles USD 1.34 lower at USD 29.63/bbl
analysis_details: Oil prices settled lower to start the week after paring gains from reports of additional OPEC cuts. The crude oil futures had already been trundling lower into the European session as equity futures reversed gains after the Globex open on Sunday. However, oil prices jumped higher after the tape was hit with reports that Saudi Aramco was to take an additional 1mln BPD cut in June from its April levels, in addition to the recent OPEC+ agreement. Saudi noted the additional cuts were being made to expedite the rebalancing of the oil market. The Kingdom also said it had directed Aramco to seek to make additional cuts in May too. Following the announcement, Kuwait announced it is to cut its output by an additional 80k BPD in June; UAE Energy Minister said the country would take an additional 100k BPD cut in June. While the announcements saw futures move into the green, they ultimately faded back into negative territory as the Europeans wrapped up for the day. Citi’s energy analysts interpreted the reversal as a suggestion that the cuts were more defensive than the Saudi commenting about “getting ahead of the curve” would suggest. Perhaps it is telling that oil futures failed to benefit in the revived appetite for equities after the US cash equity open, although one could argue that today’s rally was that of a momentum/defensive nature, with value/cyclical sectors the underperformers, thus limiting energy demand too.

subject: FX WRAP: USDJPY sees largest intraday gain since March
analysis_details:
USD: The DXY reclaimed 100 to the upside in a solid day of gains amid risk averse morning trade, with equities opening in the red while haven sectors outperformed. A similar view was seen in FX with USD bid and cyclicals underperforming, although typical havens JPY/XAU/CHF were weaker against a rising dollar.

CNY: US/China reaffirmation of Phase One obligations has eased market concerns in the short-run, but are unlikely to end tensions given US elections in November, difficulties China might have in meeting its USD 200bln purchase agreement; that has evidently been seen in some of the punchy US/China trade headlines crossing the tape today, and while they did not result in distinct risk-off, they did inject a slight negative bias. Last week, Trump said he'd address the progress of Phase One within a week or two. GS explains that rising tensions can impact the yuan via reduced cross-border M&A and portfolio flows, or lower exporter FX conversion. GS advises clients to consider adding hedges for these risks via long USDCNH or long USD/other regional FX.

JPY: The Yen was weaker against the buck with USDJPY reclaiming 107.00 and extending to highs of 107.72 at highs. Japan returned from Golden Week at the tail end of last week, although desks had anticipated a complete return would not be seen until the start of this week, which could have played into today’s price action, with USDJPY up over 1%, a move not seen since the end of March. Japanese PM Abe said the government was ready to add further stimulus if required, while it is also expected to lift its national state of emergency across parts of Japan. HSBC notes that these stories boosted local stocks thus the inverse relationship with the Nikkei could be explaining JPY weakness.

EUR: The single currency was hit today with EURUSD finding support at 1.08 after EC President Von Der Leyen raised the idea of legal action against the German Constitutional Court (GCC) after it ruled the ECB’s PSPP did not respect the “principle of proportionality” which although is in favour of the ECB, it highlights disputes among Eurozone groups.

GBP: UK PM Johnson announced the base line of the economic reopening in phases and announced that those who cannot work from home should be encouraged to return to work, while schools will start with the younger pupils first. ING writes that the speech had a muted impact as markets focus on the lack of clarity rather than the re-opening plan; the bank expects Cable to trade between 1.2240-1.2520 this week. Brexit talks are also set to get underway again, with latest reports suggesting the UK are to tell the EU a new fisheries agreement cannot be part of the free trade agreement.

CYCLICALS (GBP, AUD, NZD): Cyclicals were hit amid bouts of risk-off, although cyclicals are off lows as equities reversed losses and entered positive territory, while the haven bid for USD continued to weigh elsewhere.

analysis_details: This appears in fitting with earlier source reports, which saw further hawkish voices emerge from China calling for a re-negotiation of the Phase One deal, according to sources cited by Global Times. The piece notes of Chinese dissatisfaction amid compromises the side made to press ahead with Phase One. Officials are angered over US President Trump’s “cover up” of his handling of the pandemic – thus advisers have been floating the possibility of voiding the trade pact and renegotiating one skewed more towards China’s interests. Another official, citing US’ staggering economy and the Presidential Election, said "It's in fact in China's interests to terminate the current phase one deal. It is beneficial to us. The US now cannot afford to restart the trade war with China”. That being said, analysts believe China will only terminate the agreement as a “last option”.

subject: Daily FX Wrap: DXY dabbles with century mark as FFFs peel away from parity
content:
USD

A solid start to the week for the Dollar amidst renewed risk aversion and jitters related to the coronavirus as global economies re-emerge from lockdown. Meanwhile, reports in the Global Times suggest that some Chinese officials want to terminate the Phase one trade agreement with the US and renegotiate the terms even though last week’s call between top representatives from both sides was described as constructive and the US is said to have acknowledged that China is largely honouring pledges on structural issues. However, the Buck is outperforming all G10 rivals including the ‘safe-haven’ Yen as the front end of the curve pushes back further on sub-zero rate bets ahead of Wednesday’s speech from Fed chair Powell conscious of the fact that he has played down the prospect of NIRP in the recent past.

JPY/NZD/AUD

The Yen and Kiwi have been propping up the major table for the most part, with Usd/Jpy clearing 107.00 and April 30’s peak at 107.50 on the way to circa 107.67 against the backdrop of UST curve re-steepening into supply and more reports about a second Japanese supplementary budget. The headline pair continues to trade out of kilter with broad sentiment having extended its post-Golden Week rebound from a double base around 105.99, and technically on track for a more pronounced bounce if it closes above the 21 DMA (107.16). Elsewhere, the Kiwi has now lost grip of the 0.6100 handle in advance of Wednesday’s RNBZ when asset purchases are widely expected to be increased and the Aussie is labouring awaiting jobs data on the following day after relinquishing 0.6500+ status and weakening more than the YUAN relative to the Greenback in wake of the PBoC’s slightly softer Usd/Cny midpoint fixing and pledge to use stronger policies allied to counter-cyclical measures in support of the economy.

CAD/GBP/SEK

The Loonie got a fleeting fillip from a rebound in oil, like the NOK, RUB and MXN when Saud Arabia instructed Aramco to cut crude output by 1 mn bpd more than agreed under the OPEC+ pact, but was ultimately undermined by the risk-off mood not to mention crude prices subsequently fading after token overcompliance from Kuwait and the UAE (80k and 100k respectively vs -2 mn in total pledged by the 3 producers in April). Usd/Cad is now nearer 1.4000 than 1.3900, Eur/Nok close to 11.1400 vs just shy of 11.0200 after significantly stronger than expected Norwegian headline and core CPI, Usd/Rub midway from 73.1350 to 73.9700 and Usd/Mxn towards the upper end of a 23.5520-23.9700 band. Meanwhile, Sterling has been its usual volatile self in Cable and Eur/Gbp cross terms, but mostly weaker before the 3rd round of Brexit trade negotiations and rather unimpressed with UK PM Johnson’s calibrated approach to ending lockdown with the former whipping from 1.2437 to 1.2285 and latter between 0.8805-0.8714 parameters. Conversely, the Swedish Krona never really recovered after failing to rally through 10.5700 and the Riksbank minutes revealed what appeared to be more than just a token statement to the effect that the benchmark repo can go lower.

EUR/CHF

Relatively resilient until a late EU wave of pressure pushed the single currency closer to 1.0800 and Franc back down to the base of a 0.9701-36 corridor, but Eur/Usd held above the round number following mixed COVID-19 updates from the Eurozone, while Eur/Chf did not pay full attention to latest rises in Swiss bank sight deposit balances or comments from SNB chair Jordan explaining that it is committee to intervention and ZIRP as a means to curbing the Franc’s strength.

EM 

The Try managed to sustain its recovery momentum, albeit with volumes impaired by high volatility after Turkey’s banking regulator banned 3 foreign banks from trading, but the Czk declined amidst dovish remarks from CNB’s Holub outlining various options for stimulus if benchmark rates reach the lower bound, including QE, FX management and NIRP, though the latter would be a last resort.

subject: US EQUITY OPEN NOTE: Indices open in negative territory; Health Care the only sector in the green
analysis_details:
SNAPSHOT: Risk sentiment was initially supported at the start of the week, with US equity futures building on Friday’s late gains (with much of that rise coming after hours on Friday, in thin liquidity and volumes), some had attributed supportive PBOC policy as a driver. Though ES was able to break above the key 2,925-2,935 range to the upside, printing an overnight high of 2,947, equities have struggled to hold on to gains in the European morning, and the ES has given back its gains on little news flow and now trades in negative territory although found support at 2,900 (See here for key levels). Desks have noted that as we await new significant catalysts and headlines are thin, technical, flow-driven trade may influence price action, which appears to be what we are seeing in the pre-market; we did however get some punchy rhetoric out of China that may have resulted in caution. Treasuries are mixed ahead of Treasury supply, modestly steeper, having come off wides as equities cooled.

SECTORS: Majority of sectors open in the red while Health Care remains the only sector in the green, while staples are marginally in the red given the defensive nature of the sectors. The former is also supported by gains in Cardinal Health (CAH) after earnings. Losses today are led by Materials, Financials and Energy, with the latter failing to benefit on the rebound in prices after Saudi Arabia announced it would cut an additional 1mln BPD on top of the OPEC+ deal.

EARNINGS: Marriott (MAR) missed on EPS although beat on revenue while noting trends in Greater China are continuing to improve, adding it saw a marginal uptick in US occupancy over the past few weeks. Under Armour (UAA) missed on EPS and revenue, while announcing its quarterly restructuring and impairment chargers were USD 466mln. Cardinal Health (CAH) beat on EPS and revenue, while reaffirmed its FY20 guidance. ON Semiconductor (ON) missed on EPS and revenue, while guidance also fell short of expectations.

STOCK SPECIFICS: Tesla (TSLA) Model 3 China Sales -64% M/M in April. CEO Musk announced the Co is to leave California immediately after regulations stopped Tesla from restarting production at its Fremont factory. AbbVie (ABBV) completed its purchase of Allergan (AGN). Coty (COTY) agreed to sell its majority stake in its Wella, Clairol, OPI and GHD brands to KKR (KKR) in a USD 4.3bln deal. AMC Entertainment (AMC) reportedly held talks with Amazon (AMZN) regarding a potential takeover, according to the Daily Mail citing sources.

KEY ES LEVELS: ES has this morning fallen beneath the key 2,925-35 range (fibs, valuation); upside break brings 2,965 (Apr hi) into focus, then 3,000 (200dma, psych); downside eyes 2,890-2,900 (valuation, psych) then 2,871 (8dma). (Here for more)

VIX TERM STRUCTURE IN CONTANGO: Nomura’s quant desk suggests that some specs have gone back to building shorts in VIX, and the bank argues that derivative markets are thus giving evidence of a flow of impatiently optimistic trades that assume that the VIX will stabilize further. Nomura, composition of the rally on Friday, notes that fundamentally focussed global macro hedge funds contributed to the trend-chasing CTA’s action, though the bank warns this may be short-lived. However, Nomura argues that global macro hedge funds were expected a double-dip in developed equity markets, and they are now being forced into relenting by buying equities to cover shorts as there have been a smaller number of negative economic surprises. According to the bank, CTAs are now sidelining themselves in both stocks and bonds (may see profit-taking above 0.70% 10-year yields). “With global macro hedge funds and other investors buying equities to close out shorts, share prices have been making gains beyond what technical forecasts had pictured. Price movements this week may determine whether CTAs resume buying equity futures in a way that marks a break from the median trajectory observed during previous periods of accumulation, however, relative to economic fundamentals, the recent stock market gains are substantial enough that most of the potential for a rebound in equities has arguably already been used up.” The bank adds that any further accumulation of long positions in equity futures by CTAs could leave them taking on undue momentum risk.”

WHY THIS EQUITY RALLY IS UNLOVED: Three drivers of the current rally: slowdown in the rate of new virus infections, Fed policy actions, CARES Act (and expectations of a fourth round of stimulus. But investors appear not to love the rally. According to Goldman Sachs, 60% of mutual funds lagged their benchmark during the rally from March lows, long/short and macro hedge funds returned 8% and 1% respectively, vs SPX +31%. Some CIOs, meanwhile, have raised eyebrows at the speed of the rebounded, current stretched valuations (SPX trading with P/E of ~20 x its eps estimate), and question the potential for forward returns (170 EPS based on H2 recovery). GS suggests that one reason for the distrust in momentum may be the narrow breadth of the rally; the five largest SPX stocks account for 21% of its capitalisation, and while those big five are all up YTD, the SPX is negative. Additionally, while the SPX is 13% beneath its February all-time high, the median stock is 23% under its peak. Accordingly, GS warns of potential downside in the short-term, though suggests that it might not be a single catalyst that sparks a pullback, including 1) COVID infection rates outside of NY continue to rise, and may accelerate as lockdowns are lifted; 2) the restart process will take time; 3) bank loan loss reserves were built in Q1 based on a jobless rate of around 10% - that rate rose to 14.7% in April, and GS forecasts loan loss provisions will need to rise to USD 115bln in the next four quarters (versus total of USD 46bln in Q1); this may weigh on share repurchase/buybacks plans, shaking a key pillar of support that equities have enjoyed in the last decade; 4) dividends are at risk, and are seen falling further this year, as too are capex plans; 5) tax policy risk around elections; tax reforms in 2017 lowered corporation tax to 18% from 26%, and may become a political issue; 6) US/China risks, a headwind in 2019, are resurfacing.

EQUITY RISK PREMIA: JPM is not surprised that equities are rallying while economic data points paint a grim picture. JPM still sees S&P 500 of recovering its losses and reaching 3,400 (new highs) in H1 2021. JPM argues that even if a second wave of outbreaks were to occur, the Fed has explicitly indicated that there is no dollar limit and no danger of running out of ammunition. Monetary policy (rates cuts, credit spread compression) and fiscal support (direct payments) have put a floor under stocks. JPM says this stimulus and liquidity will outlast the health crisis, and equity risk premia is attractive (most attractive for Nasdaq, Secular Growth and Sustainable Income stocks over the medium-to-long term). The bank notes that historically equity risk premia tend to compress after the introduction of QE, rising free liquidity ratios, negative real rates and tightening credit spreads. It calculates equity risk premia for the S&P 500 is around 9.4% versus the long-term average of 5.7%. This is supported by historically low rates, negative real rates, and cheap credit. “These are powerful tailwinds for equity multiples, in our view, especially in the US which is the home of a large number of Sustainable Income and Long Duration stocks,” JPMorgan writes, “a comparison of current equity multiple to its history may not fully appreciate the benefit of low nominal and negative real rates for valuation.”

NEGATIVE RATES: Fed Funds futures for the turn of the year rose above par last week, signalling a probability above zero that the Fed could lower rates into negative territory next year. The moves above par were modest, and pared back at the end of the week (Nov 2020 FF was above par early Friday, but only the Feb 2021 contract closed out the week at/above par). Goldman Sachs is surprised by market's implying negative yields (even if modest) given that Fed speakers have generally been averse to such moves. GS says that, while it is hard to rule out, the pricing in seems a bit aggressive given current expectations for the economy, and even if the Fed were to explore negative rates, it would likely be reluctant to go deep, given political issues with penalising cash. Other think the pricing of negative rates might be more technical in nature. Fed chief Powell is due to speak on Wednesday, and the theme will be monitored, particularly by equity investors, given the upside seen last week after the Fed Funds futures rose above par.

subject: ECB PEPP +34.097bln vs. Prev. EUR +22.092bln; Total holding EUR 152.907bln
ECB APP: PSPP EUR +7.114bln (Prev. EUR -0.738bln), CSPP EUR +2.575bln (Prev. EUR -0.062bln), CBPP3 EUR +1.024bln (Prev. EUR -0.231bln), ABSPP EUR +0.018bln (Prev. EUR -0.267bln)
analysis_details:
• Last week printed a net-sale across the APP for the first time, heavily in contrast to this weeks purchases which see a total of EUR 10.731bln purchased;  a figure which, omitting the previous week momentarily, would be relatively in-line with the most recent APP totals.
  • Last week, for the PSPP in particular much focus was on the GCC ruling (recap and analysis available here) rather than the actual magnitude/directionality of purchases.
  • On Friday, ratings action for Italy from both DBRS and Moody’s has drawn substantial attention; action which saw Moody’s maintain their rating at Baa3 while, perhaps more notably, DBRS elected to cut their trend from ‘Stable’ to ‘Negative’. Follows on from S&P maintain their rating for Italy at BBB a few weeks ago as well. Much attention has been on the rating of Italy, given the extent to which it has been impacted by COVID-19 and the significant stimulus measures they have had to take to counter this. Following the ECB’s ‘Fallen Angels’ announcement a few weeks ago, reports have since noted the ECB has begun looking into the purchases of junk corporate debt (similar to the Fed); which, again, is potentially particularly of note for Italy as the very real prospect of it being cut to Junk rating would likely see a number of Italian companies fall as well.
  • Until this week, PEPP has continued to trend around the EUR 20bln mark, and has remained relatively consistent around this figure; differing notably from the substantial swings seen in the APP operations recently – perhaps indicating the ECB is being to favour conducting its policy via this mechanism. This weeks substantial increase of EUR +34.097bln (Prev. +22.092bln), which equates to +54.34% (Prev. +10.17%) appears to chime with this narrative; however, it is perhaps too early to say for sure as the programme still has some way to run with only EUR 152.907bln of the EUR 750bln currently allotted purchases thus far. As a reminder COVID-19 related policies (PEPP and PELTROs so far) were exempt from the GCC ruling on proportionality last week.

ANALYSIS: Hawkish China voices call for termination of US Phase One deal
content:
OVERVIEW: Further hawkish voices have emerged from China calling for a re-negotiation of the Phase One deal, according to sources cited by Global Times. The piece notes of Chinese dissatisfaction amid compromises the side made to press ahead with Phase One. Officials are angered over US President Trump’s “cover up” of his handling of the pandemic – thus advisers have been floating the possibility of voiding the trade pact and renegotiating one skewed more towards China’s interests. Another official, citing US’ staggering economy and the Presidential Election, said "It's in fact in China's interests to terminate the current phase one deal. It is beneficial to us. The US now cannot afford to restart the trade war with China”. That being said, analysts believe China will only terminate the agreement as a “last option”.

US-CHINA PHONE CALL: Over the weekend, US source familiar with recent discussions stated US officials acknowledged China was largely delivering its pledges on structural issues such as opening market access and improving IP protection but they have yet to agree in some details including IP action plan and easing equity caps for foreign investors. Furthermore, the source stated fallout from the virus meant agreement on purchasing US goods has become much more important and that many believe China needs to increase pace on purchases, while reports also noted that a Chinese government adviser suggested the deal itself was fragile.

US VISA RESTRICTIONS: Sentiment deteriorated from another angle after the Trump administration imposed a 90-day on Chinese jounalists' work visas vs. the previous open-ended stay granted to most journalists with Chinese passports.  Chinese Foreign Ministry urged US to immediately correct its mistakes regarding new US visa rule for Chinese journalist, otherwise China will have to take countermeasures.

RECENT RHETORIC:

  • US: US President Trump recently threatened to terminate the deal with China should it not adhere to its commitments under the Phase One deal. Furthermore, the US President floated the idea of tariffs as a potential punishment for China’s handling of the pandemic. Trump has blamed China for playing down the scale and risks of the virus – a move believed to be correlated to the US Presidential Election.
  • CHINA: China has blamed US officials for attempting to shift their “poor handling” of the pandemic. Analysts via SCMP noted that China can retaliate by dumping its US Treasury holdings whilst imposing tariffs of their own, albeit Chinese officials yesterday noted that tariffs should not be used as a weapon. Meanwhile, underlying soured sentiment remains on the Hong Kong front – Chinese Foreign Ministry said it opposes US interference on China's affairs with Hong Kong.

TRADE DATA: The Chinese trade data for April printed a substantially larger than the expected surplus in CNY and USD terms as the nation resurfaces from lockdown. However, China's trade with the US continued to decline from January to April, the total value of China-US trade dropped 12.8% whilst China's imports from the US slid 3% and exports plunged 15.9%, according to Global Time

analysis_details:

subject: US PRE-MARKET THEMES: Equity futures give up early gains; supply floodgates are open; why this rally is unloved; This week: Powell on Wednesday, retail sales, CPI
analysis_details:
MARKET SNAPSHOT: Risk sentiment was supported at the start of the week, with US equity futures building on Friday’s late gains (with much of that rise coming after hours on Friday, in thin liquidity and volumes), some had attributed supportive PBOC policy as a driver. Though ES was able to break above the key 2,925-2,935 range to the upside, printing an overnight high of 2,947, equities have struggled to hold on to gains in the European morning, and the ES has given back its gains on little news flow. Desks have noted that as we await new significant catalysts and headlines are thin, technical, flow-driven trade may influence price action, which appears to be what we are seeing in the pre-market. Treasuries are a little off on the day, with a steeper bias; the DXY is slightly firmer.

KEY NEWS FLOW: PBOC has pledged greater policy support. German/EU politics are getting some attention again. Trump and US chipmakers including Intel (INTC) are seeking semiconductor self-sufficiency, the WSJ reported, and are looking to jump-start development of new factories in the US amid concerns about the reliance on Asia for a source of key technology. Airlines are soft in the UK as the government announced quarantine for arrivals, as well as a warning from IAG LN on demand. French autos are faring better than most after French Finance Minister said the State was ready to help the auto industry, but production must first be brought back to France. Italy’s government is said to be mulling state guarantees for up to EUR 15bln of bonds issued by banks, according to a draft decree.

THIS WEEK: Powell, CPI, retail sales on deck. Our week ahead briefing can be accessed here. Our central bank weekly briefing can be accessed here (and recent commentary on negative rates can be found here). 

SUPPLY FLOODGATES ARE OPEN: The Treasury will auction USD 42bln 3-year notes (Mon), USD 32bln 10-year notes (Tue), and USD 22bln 30-year bonds (Wed). This week's auction will be revealing, given the Treasury's boosted refunding announcement last week. Our previews for this week’s auctions can be found here. Additionally, this week’s Fed bond buying has been scaled-back again, with most of the cuts in the short-end (details here).

KEY ES LEVELS: ES has this morning fallen beneath the key 2,925-35 range (fibs, valuation); upside break brings 2,965 (Apr hi) into focus, then 3,000 (200dma, psych); downside eyes 2,890-2,900 (valuation, psych) then 2,871 (8dma). (Here for more)

VIX TERM STRUCTURE IN CONTANGO: Nomura’s quant desk suggests that some specs have gone back to building shorts in VIX, and the bank argues that derivative markets are thus giving evidence of a flow of impatiently optimistic trades that assume that the VIX will stabilize further. Nomura, composition of the rally on Friday, notes that fundamentally focussed global macro hedge funds contributed to the trend-chasing CTA’s action, though the bank warns this may be short-lived. However, Nomura argues that global macro hedge funds were expected a double-dip in developed equity markets, and they are now being forced into relenting by buying equities to cover shorts as there have been a smaller number of negative economic surprises. According to the bank, CTAs are now sidelining themselves in both stocks and bonds (may see profit-taking above 0.70% 10-year yields). “With global macro hedge funds and other investors buying equities to close out shorts, share prices have been making gains beyond what technical forecasts had pictured. Price movements this week may determine whether CTAs resume buying equity futures in a way that marks a break from the median trajectory observed during previous periods of accumulation, however, relative to economic fundamentals, the recent stock market gains are substantial enough that most of the potential for a rebound in equities has arguably already been used up.” The bank adds that any further accumulation of long positions in equity futures by CTAs could leave them taking on undue momentum risk.”

WHY THIS EQUITY RALLY IS UNLOVED: Three drivers of the current rally: slowdown in the rate of new virus infections, Fed policy actions, CARES Act (and expectations of a fourth round of stimulus. But investors appear not to love the rally. According to Goldman Sachs, 60% of mutual funds lagged their benchmark during the rally from March lows, long/short and macro hedge funds returned 8% and 1% respectively, vs SPX +31%. Some CIOs, meanwhile, have raised eyebrows at the speed of the rebounded, current stretched valuations (SPX trading with P/E of ~20 x its eps estimate), and question the potential for forward returns (170 EPS based on H2 recovery). GS suggests that one reason for the distrust in momentum may be the narrow breadth of the rally; the five largest SPX stocks account for 21% of its capitalisation, and while those big five are all up YTD, the SPX is negative. Additionally, while the SPX is 13% beneath its February all-time high, the median stock is 23% under its peak. Accordingly, GS warns of potential downside in the short-term, though suggests that it might not be a single catalyst that sparks a pullback, including 1) COVID infection rates outside of NY continue to rise, and may accelerate as lockdowns are lifted; 2) the restart process will take time; 3) bank loan loss reserves were built in Q1 based on a jobless rate of around 10% - that rate rose to 14.7% in April, and GS forecasts loan loss provisions will need to rise to USD 115bln in the next four quarters (versus total of USD 46bln in Q1); this may weigh on share repurchase/buybacks plans, shaking a key pillar of support that equities have enjoyed in the last decade; 4) dividends are at risk, and are seen falling further this year, as too are capex plans; 5) tax policy risk around elections; tax reforms in 2017 lowered corporation tax to 18% from 26%, and may become a political issue; 6) US/China risks, a headwind in 2019, are resurfacing.

EQUITY RISK PREMIA: JPM is not surprised that equities are rallying while economic data points paint a grim picture. JPM still sees S&P 500 of recovering its losses and reaching 3,400 (new highs) in H1 2021. JPM argues that even if a second wave of outbreaks were to occur, the Fed has explicitly indicated that there is no dollar limit and no danger of running out of ammunition. Monetary policy (rates cuts, credit spread compression) and fiscal support (direct payments) have put a floor under stocks. JPM says this stimulus and liquidity will outlast the health crisis, and equity risk premia is attractive (most attractive for Nasdaq, Secular Growth and Sustainable Income stocks over the medium-to-long term). The bank notes that historically equity risk premia tend to compress after the introduction of QE, rising free liquidity ratios, negative real rates and tightening credit spreads. It calculates equity risk premia for the S&P 500 is around 9.4% versus the long-term average of 5.7%. This is supported by historically low rates, negative real rates, and cheap credit. “These are powerful tailwinds for equity multiples, in our view, especially in the US which is the home of a large number of Sustainable Income and Long Duration stocks,” JPMorgan writes, “a comparison of current equity multiple to its history may not fully appreciate the benefit of low nominal and negative real rates for valuation.”

NEGATIVE RATES: Fed Funds futures for the turn of the year rose above par last week, signalling a probability above zero that the Fed could lower rates into negative territory next year. The moves above par were modest, and pared back at the end of the week (Nov 2020 FF was above par early Friday, but only the Feb 2021 contract closed out the week at/above par). Goldman Sachs is surprised by market's implying negative yields (even if modest) given that Fed speakers have generally been averse to such moves. GS says that, while it is hard to rule out, the pricing in seems a bit aggressive given current expectations for the economy, and even if the Fed were to explore negative rates, it would likely be reluctant to go deep, given political issues with penalising cash. Other think the pricing of negative rates might be more technical in nature. Fed chief Powell is due to speak on Wednesday, and the theme will be monitored, particularly by equity investors, given the upside seen last week after the Fed Funds futures rose above par.
